triples.name: Game theory
triples.relevance: Game theory provides the foundational framework for analyzing strategic interactions between the central decision maker and distributed processes in the game model.

triples.name: Automata theory
triples.relevance: Automata theory underlies the non-deterministic asynchronous automata model on which the distributed games are played.

triples.name: Finite-state machine
triples.relevance: The paper proposes novel finite-state distributed strategies that extend classical finite-state machines to the distributed setting.

triples.name: Safety property
triples.relevance: Safety is one of the two key objective types for which the paper provides algorithmic solutions for distributed games.

triples.name: Parity game
triples.relevance: Parity objectives are the second key objective type for which the paper develops algorithmic solutions and establishes finite-state strategy existence.

triples.name: Distributed computing
triples.relevance: Distributed computing provides the systems perspective for the multi-agent processes coordinating through a central decision maker.

triples.name: Information asymmetry
triples.relevance: Partial information games rely on asymmetric information distribution among processes, which is captured by information asymmetry concepts.

triples.name: Scheduling (computing)
triples.relevance: Scheduling is a core concept where the scheduler makes decisions that distributed processes respond to in the game-theoretic framework.
